[[No. 285 Squadron RAAF|No. 285 Squadron]] }} {{stack end}} '''No. 84 Wing''' is a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) transport [[Wing (air force unit)|wing]]. Coming under the control of [[Air Mobility Group RAAF|Air Mobility Group]] (AMG), it is headquartered at [[RAAF Base Richmond]], New South Wales. The wing comprises [[No. 34 Squadron RAAF|No. 34 Squadron]], operating [[Boeing Business Jet|Boeing 737]] and [[Bombardier Challenger 604]] [[Very Important Person|VIP]] jets; [[No. 37 Squadron RAAF|No. 37 Squadron]], operating [[Lockheed Martin C-130J Super Hercules]] medium transports; and a technical training unit, [[No. 285 Squadron RAAF|No. 285 Squadron]]. Formed in 1944 for [[Close air support|army co-operation]] duties in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II]], No. 84 Wing operated a mix of aircraft including [[CAC Boomerang]]s, [[CAC Wirraway]]s, [[Taylorcraft Auster|Auster AOPs]] and [[Bristol Beaufort]]s, before disbanding in 1946. It was re-formed in 1991 as a tactical transport wing headquartered at [[RAAF Base Townsville]], Queensland, comprising [[No. 35 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 35]] and [[No. 38 Squadron RAAF|38 Squadrons]] operating [[de Havilland Canada DHC-4 Caribou]]s. By 1996, it had been augmented by [[No. 32 Squadron RAAF|No. 32 Squadron]], operating [[Hawker Siddeley HS 748]] trainer-transports. In 1998, No. 84 Wing was reorganised as a special transport wing, headquartered at Richmond. The Caribous were transferred to [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 Wing]] and No. 84 Wing took over responsibility for [[No. 33 Squadron RAAF|No. 33 Squadron]], operating [[Boeing 707]] [[Aerial refueling|tanker]]-transports, and No. 34 Squadron, operating VIP transports, in addition to controlling No. 32 Squadron. By mid-2006, No. 32 Squadron had converted to [[Beechcraft King Air|Beech King Air 350s]] and transferred to [[Air Force Training Group RAAF|Air Force Training Group]], while No. 84 Wing had assumed control of No. 285 Squadron and [[Air Movements Training and Development Unit RAAF|Air Movements Training and Development Unit]] (AMTDU). AMTDU was subsequently moved under the direct aegis of ALG, and No. 33 Squadron under No. 86 Wing, following the retirement of the 707s. No. 37 Squadron, by then the RAAF's sole Hercules unit, was transferred from No. 86 Wing to No. 84 Wing in 2010. No. 35 Squadron, which had been merged with No. 38 Squadron in 2000, was re-formed under No. 84 Wing in 2013 to operate [[Alenia C-27J Spartan]] tactical transport commencing in 2015; the squadron was detached from the wing in January 2014 but is scheduled to return as the Spartan becomes operational. ==History== ===Army cooperation formation=== {{stack|[[File:No. 5 Sqn Boomerang (AWM OG3258).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Boomerang of No. 5 Squadron on Bougainville|alt=Single-engined military monoplane with propeller spinning, on jungle airfield]]}} The [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) established two [[Close air support|army cooperation]] [[Wing (air force unit)|wings]] in the [[South West Pacific Theatre of World War II|South West Pacific Theatre]] late in World War II.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/19.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 318–327]Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/26.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 440] They were, as described by the [[Australia in the War of 1939–1945|official history of the RAAF in the Pacific]], "essentially non-offensive in character", responsible for reconnaissance, artillery spotting, supply drops to ground forces, spraying [[DDT]] to combat [[malaria]], and guiding close support aircraft to their objectives. The wing's aircraft could also carry out their own strikes on "targets of opportunity".Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/18.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 317] No. 84 (Army Cooperation) Wing was formed on 11 September 1944 in [[Cairns]], Queensland.{{cite magazine|magazine=Air Force News |volume=41 |issue=9|date= October 1999|page=18|title=Bulletin board}} Commanded by Group Captain [[William Hely|Bill Hely]], it comprised [[No. 5 Squadron RAAF|No. 5 (Tactical Reconnaissance) Squadron]], [[No. 17 Air Observation Post Flight RAAF|No. 17 Air Observation Post (AOP) Flight]], No. 10 Communication Unit, and No. 39 Operational Base Unit. The wing arrived at [[Torokina]] in October to begin supporting Australian troops during the [[Bougainville Campaign]].Parnell; Lynch, ''Australian Air Force Since 1911'', p. 97 No. 5 Squadron, equipped with eighteen [[CAC Boomerang]]s and four [[CAC Wirraway]]s, was assigned to mark targets for [[Vought F4U Corsair|F4U Corsairs]] of the [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]]. The [[Taylorcraft Auster|Austers]] of No. 17 AOP Flight were used for reconnaissance and courier work, becoming, in the words of the official history, "the eyes of the battalion commanders". No. 10 Communications Unit flew [[Avro Anson]]s and [[Bristol Beaufort]]s on courier, reconnaissance, supply, and anti-malarial spraying missions; it was renamed [[No. 10 Local Air Supply Unit RAAF|No. 10 Local Air Supply Unit]] in March 1945.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maritime and Transport Units'', pp. 145–147 Between December 1944 and January 1945, the wing lost one Auster, one Wirraway, and one Boomerang on operations. [[File:No. 17 AOP Flight Auster (AWM 107054).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Auster of No. 17 AOP Flight over Bougainville|alt=Single-engined high-wing light plane flying over water, with jungle terrain in background]] Despite suffering shortages of pilots and equipment, No. 84 Wing was generally able to keep pace with the army's requirements.Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 389–390 A detachment of [[No. 36 Squadron RAAF|No. 36 Squadron]], flying [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|C-47 Dakotas]], was employed to augment the wing's supply capabilities. Up until the end of June 1945, No. 5 Squadron had flown almost 2,000 [[sortie]]s and No. 17 AOP Flight over 1,300, while No. 10 Local Air Supply Unit and the No. 36 Squadron detachment had accounted for almost 1,000 between them. As the navigational efficiency of the New Zealander pilots increased, demands on the Boomerangs and Wirraways lessened, and the bulk of the reconnaissance duties fell to the Austers of No. 17 AOP Flight. When the Pacific War ended in August 1945, No. 10 Local Air Supply Unit was tasked with dropping leaflets announcing the news over Japanese positions. That month, Group Captain D.R. Chapman succeeded Hely as No. 84 Wing's commander. The end of hostilities led to morale problems owing to inactivity and the uncertainties of demobilisation; Chapman sent [[No. 9 Operational Group RAAF|Northern Command]] headquarters a frank report to this effect, its tone earning him a rebuke from the [[Air Officer Commanding]], Air Commodore [[Allan Walters]].{{cite web|author=No. 84 (Army Co-operation) Wing|title=Operations record book |url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=1753386| pages=21–23, 31|accessdate=26 May 2013}} No. 17 AOP Flight was disbanded on Bougainville in December, followed a month later by No. 10 Local Air Supply Unit.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maritime and Transport Units'', pp. 172–173 No. 5 Squadron transferred to [[RAAF Base Pearce|RAAF Station Pearce]], Western Australia, in January 1946, and disbanded in October that year.{{cite web|url= http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11027second_world_war.asp|title =No 5 Squadron RAAF|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=18 May 2013}} No. 84 Wing headquarters completed "reduction to nucleus" at Bougainville on 29 January 1946.{{cite web|author=Royal Australian Air Force|title=No. 84 (Army Co-operation) Wing accounting inspection |url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=1697620| page= 4|accessdate=26 May 2013}} It departed Torakina and arrived in [[Essendon, Victoria|Essendon]], Victoria, on 28 February, disbanding there on 6 March.AWM, ''Squadrons, Formations & Units of the Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 121 ===Transport formation=== [[File:Royal Australian Air Force DHC-4 Caribou - A4-299.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|RAAF DHC-4 Caribou|alt=Twin-engined military cargo plane parked on airfield]] No. 84 Wing was re-established as a tactical transport wing under the newly formed [[Combat Support Group RAAF|Operational Support Group]] (OSG) at [[RAAF Base Townsville]], Queensland, in February 1991.RAAF Historical section, ''Introduction, Bases, Supporting Organisations'', p. 162 It comprised two squadrons of [[de Havilland DHC-4 Caribou]]s: [[No. 35 Squadron RAAF|No. 35 Squadron]], located at Townsville, and [[No. 38 Squadron RAAF|No. 38 Squadron]], located at [[RAAF Base Richmond]], New South Wales.{{cite magazine|magazine=RAAF News |volume=34 |issue=1|date=February 1992|page=15|title=Aircraft of the RAAF: A4 – DHC Caribou}} Prior to this, the two squadrons had been under the control of Tactical Transport Group, OSG's predecessor at Townsville.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 104 No. 84 Wing's primary purpose was to support [[Australian Army]] operations and exercises, as well as the [[Parachute Training School (Australian Army)|Parachute Training School]] at [[HMAS Albatross (air station)|HMAS Albatross]] in [[Nowra, New South Wales|Nowra]], New South Wales. It also maintained detachments for search-and-rescue and local transport duties at [[RAAF Base Darwin]], Northern Territory, and RAAF Base Pearce, Western Australia. The Pearce detachment (No. 38 Squadron Detachment A) was formed from [[No. 2 Flying Training School RAAF|No. 2 Flying Training School]]'s Caribou Flight on 1 March 1991.{{cite magazine|magazine=RAAF News |volume=34 |issue=1|date=February 1992|page=21|title=Special tour for Caribou}} In addition to their military role, the Caribous provided assistance to the civil community in the form of disaster relief and medical evacuation.{{cite magazine|title=From Tiger Moths to tactical transport|magazine=Air Force Today |volume=1 |issue=1|date=May 1996|pages=16–17}} The aircraft frequently operated in Papua New Guinea, for training and humanitarian missions.McPhedran, ''Air Force'', pp. 64–65 No. 38 Squadron, responsible for all Caribou aircrew conversion and operations training, transferred to [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland, in October 1992.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maritime and Transport Units'', pp. 48, 67{{cite magazine|title=TAC airlift|magazine=Air Force Today |volume=1 |issue=2|date =July 1996|pages=24–27}} Beginning the following month, seven of the fleet's twenty-one Caribous were retired to storage at Amberley for use as spare parts.{{cite web |url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/35sqn.htm |title= No 35 Squadron |publisher=[[RAAF Museum]] |accessdate=19 May 2012}} By mid-1996, No. 84 Wing was under the control of [[Air Lift Group RAAF|Air Lift Group]] (ALG), located at Richmond, and had been augmented by [[No. 32 Squadron RAAF|No. 32 Squadron]], operating [[Hawker Siddeley HS 748]]s for navigational training, [[Very Important Person|VIP]] transport, and fisheries surveillance out of [[RAAF Base East Sale]] in Victoria.{{cite magazine|title=32 Squadron multi-role|magazine=Air Force Today |volume=1 |issue=1|date=May 1996|pages=30–31}}Odgers, ''Air Force Australia'', pp. 192–193, 196–197 [[File:RAAF EB-707 (33 Sqn) refuelling a US Navy F-A-18 Hornet (VFA-131).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|No. 33 Squadron 707 refuelling a [[United States Navy|US Navy]] F/A-18 Hornet during the war in Afghanistan, April 2002|alt=Air-to-air view of four-engined jet transport refuelling fighter plane]] In January 1998, No. 84 Wing was reorganised as a special transport wing under ALG, "special transport" meaning activities not directly related to army support, such as carrying VIPs.Odgers, '' Air Force Australia'', p. 206 Its headquarters was relocated to Richmond. In addition to No. 32 Squadron, its complement included [[No. 33 Squadron RAAF|No. 33 Squadron]], operating [[Boeing 707]]s for [[Aerial refueling|air-to-air refuelling]] and VIP transport out of Richmond, and No. 34 Squadron, operating [[Falcon 900]]s for VIP transport out of [[Fairbairn, Canberra|RAAF Base Fairbairn]] in Canberra. Nos. 35 and 38 Squadrons meanwhile transferred to [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 Wing]], also headquartered at Richmond.{{cite book|title=Defence Annual Report 1997–98|chapter=Australian Defence Force Units and Establishments|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/budget/97-98/dar/full.pdf|publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]]|accessdate=16 May 2013|page=53}} Two of No. 33 Squadron's five 707s were soon employed to form No. 84 Wing Detachment A in Kuwait, as part of [[Operation Southern Watch]]. On 5 March, one of the 707s undertook the first operational aerial tanker mission since the squadron's re-formation in 1983, when it refuelled six [[Panavia Tornado]]s of the [[Royal Air Force]] (RAF) over Saudi Arabia. The detachment subsequently refuelled US [[Northrop Grumman EA-6B Prowler|EA-6 Prowler]]s, [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet|F/A-18 Hornet]]s, and [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|AV-8 Harrier]]s, as well as RAF Harriers, in addition to the Tornados.{{cite magazine|magazine=Air Force News |volume=40 |issue=3|date= April 1998|page=1|title= Gulf 707s operational}}{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/minister/1998/07398.html|title=Australian Defence Force contingent deployment to the Gulf to continue|date=8 May 1998|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=16 May 2013}} From March to September 2002, two 707s formed No. 84 Wing Detachment as part of [[Operation Slipper|Australia's contribution to the war in Afghanistan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/minister/17tpl.cfm?CurrentId=1330|title=Farewell of 84 WG Detachment|publisher=Department of Defence|date=15 March 2002|accessdate=18 May 2013}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4419/topstories/story01.htm|last=Caddaye|first=Ben|title=Well done|magazine=Air Force|volume=44 |issue= 19|date= 10 October 2002|accessdate=18 May 2013}} Located at [[Transit Center at Manas|Manas Air Base]] in [[Kyrgyzstan]], the 707s provided aerial refuelling to coalition aircraft operating in the theatre, their efforts earning No. 84 Wing a [[Meritorious Unit Citation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/health/infocentre/journals/ADFHJ_apr04/ADFHealth_5_1_bc.pdf|last=Seah|first=Mike|title=84 Wing Detachment, Ganci Air Base, Manas, Kyrgyzstan|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=18 May 2013}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4419/topstories/story02.htm|title=84WG awarded unit citation|magazine=Air Force|volume=44|issue=19|date= 10 October 2002|accessdate=18 May 2013}} No. 34 Squadron's fleet of five Falcon 900s was replaced by two [[Boeing Business Jet|Boeing 737 Business Jets]] and three [[Bombardier Challenger 604]]s in July 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series3/A37.htm|title=Challenger CL 604|publisher=RAAF Museum|accessdate=18 May 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Lift-Group/No.-84-Wing/No.-34-Squadron/?RAAF-5osdukf6+PE5/jEXa17cEq3aEiQLl43C |title=No. 34 Squadron's aircraft|publisher =Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=4 June 2013}} The arrival of the new jets also permitted the Air Force to cease using No. 33 Squadron's 707s in the VIP transport role.{{cite journal|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate_Committees?url=fadt_ctte/estimates/sup_0809/def/ans_def_updated_q5_oct08.pdf|work=Budget Supplementary Estimates; October 2008|title=Answers to questions on notice from the Department of Defence|publisher=Department of Defence|date=27 January 2009|accessdate=6 June 2013}} In concert with the No. 84 Wing Navigation Training Aircraft Detachment, No. 32 Squadron completed its conversion from the HS 748 to the [[Beechcraft King Air|Beech King Air 350]] in December 2004.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4703/international/international04.htm|last=Liebelt|first=Simone|author2=Johnson, Peter |title=King Air’s debut role|magazine=Air Force|volume= 47|issue= 3|date=10 March 2005|accessdate=16 May 2013}} By mid-2006, the squadron had been transferred to [[Air Force Training Group RAAF|Air Force Training Group]] and No. 84 Wing had assumed control of two Richmond-based units from the defunct [[No. 85 Wing RAAF|No. 85 Wing]], [[No. 285 Squadron RAAF|No. 285 Squadron]] and the [[Air Movements Training and Development Unit RAAF|Air Movements Training and Development Unit]] (AMTDU).{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4717/features/feature01.htm|title=Lifting the bar|magazine=Air Force |volume= 47|issue= 17|date=22 September 2005|accessdate=16 May 2013}}{{cite book|title=Defence Annual Report 2005–06|date=30 June 2006|chapter=ADF Units and Establishments|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/budget/05-06/dar/web_only_section/05_adf.html|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=16 May 2013}} No. 285 Squadron undertook instruction of technical staff, and ground-based aircrew training using Hercules and Boeing 707 [[flight simulator]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Lift-Group/No.-84-Wing/No.-285-Squadron/?RAAF-llxKqiw2TQw3ktO3/X3MtuMd6E4wvKSC|title=No. 285 Squadron's history|publisher=[[Royal Australian Air Force]]|accessdate=18 May 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/download/2008/jun/20080626/|title=No. 285 Squadron Boeing 707 Simulator Decommissioning|date=26 June 2008|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=2 June 2013}} AMTDU was responsible for developing and disseminating new techniques in air transport operations.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 99 It was later moved under the direct control of Headquarters ALG.{{cite web|title=Restructure of Air Lift Group units |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/download/2010/Oct/20101005c/index.htm|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=5 October 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Lift-Group?RAAF-sNFA62I5DlLtVOqidVYBjGwjkHSoZlFd|title=Air Lift Group|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=18 May 2013}} No. 33 Squadron retired its 707s in June 2008, and subsequently relocated to Amberley under the control of No. 86 Wing.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/33sqn.htm|title=No 33 Squadron|publisher=RAAF Museum|accessdate=16 May 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About_us/Structure_of_the_RAAF/Air_Command/Air_Lift_Group/No._86_Wing/?RAAF-L/vGzk7TMG7p5QeGWqFzal55alCa8iJ6 |title= No. 86 Wing|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate= 2 April 2013}} [[File:RAAF Boeing 737-7DT(BBJ) CBR Gilbert-1.jpg||thumb|right|upright=1.2|No. 34 Squadron 737 in Canberra, April 2004|alt=Twin-engined passenger jet in fight]] No. 37 Squadron transferred from No. 86 Wing to No. 84 Wing in October 2010. It operated a mix of [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|Lockheed C-130H Hercules]] and [[Lockheed Martin C-130J Super Hercules]], No. 86 Wing having consolidated all its C-130 operations in the one squadron, prior to re-equipping No. 36 Squadron with the [[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III]].{{cite web|title=Royal Australian Air Force squadrons celebrate new role |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/DepartmentalTpl.cfm?CurrentId=6145 |publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=17 November 2006}} The Hercules, along with Globemasters and King Airs, were employed for [[2010–2011 Queensland floods|flood relief in Queensland]] and [[Early 2011 Victorian floods|Victoria early in 2011]].{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/Operations/Humanitarian-support/?RAAF-hruuHkflEaNxq4BtnrEKSQz5XM3LaPec|title=Humanitarian support|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=6 May 2013}}{{cite magazine|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|title=Flood assist |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/5301/5301.pdf |magazine=Air Force|volume= 53|issue=1|pages=4–5|accessdate=16 May 2013|date= 3 February 2011}} In February, Hercules and Globemasters transported medical staff and equipment to aid victims of the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|Christchurch earthquake]].McPhedran, ''Air Force'', pp. 237–238 The same year, No. 34 Squadron provided VIP transport during the visits to Australia by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] and US President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Lift-Group/No.-84-Wing/No.-34-Squadron/?RAAF-5osdukf6+PE5/jEXa17cEq3aEiQLl43C |title=No. 34 Squadron's history|publisher =Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=28 May 2013}} No. 37 Squadron's C-130H Hercules were retired in November 2012; the C-130Js are expected to remain in service until about 2030.{{cite magazine|last=Pittaway|first=Nigel|title=C-130J upgrade – Keeping the Hercules current|magazine=Defence Today |volume=10 |issue=2 |date=March 2013|pages=16–17}}{{cite magazine|title=C-130H retired from service|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2012/11/c-130h-retired-from-service/|accessdate=12 April 2013|magazine=[[Australian Aviation (magazine)|Australian Aviation]]|date=30 November 2012}} In February 2013, the RAAF marked ten years rotating a detachment of three C-130s through the [[Middle East Area of Operations]] (MEAO) to support the Australian contribution to the wars in Afghanistan and [[Australian contribution to the 2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq]], a rotation maintained by No. 37 Squadron under the auspices of No. 84 Wing.McPhedran, ''Air Force'', p. 11{{cite magazine|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/5503/5503.pdf|title=Keeping up ops|magazine=Air Force |volume=55 |issue=3|date=28 February 2013|page=4|accessdate=18 May 2013}} Its operations having been absorbed by No. 38 Squadron in 2000, No. 35 Squadron was re-established under No. 84 Wing on 14 January 2013, to operate ten [[Alenia C-27J Spartan]] tactical transports out of Richmond.{{cite magazine|title=RAAF C-27J buy confirmed|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2012/05/raaf-c-27j-buy-confirmed/|accessdate=19 May 2012|magazine=Australian Aviation|date=10 May 2012}} The squadron was transferred to the C-27J Transition Team on 21 January 2014, and is expected to return to No. 84 Wing's control upon the Spartan reaching [[initial operating capability]]; the first of the new aircraft arrived in Australia on 25 June 2015.{{cite magazine|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=86622#folio=2|title=Spartan's maiden flight|magazine=Air Force |volume=56 |issue=1|date=30 January 2014|page=3|accessdate=28 January 2014}}{{cite magazine|title=First RAAF C-27J touches down|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2015/06/first-raaf-c-27j-touches-down-at-richmond/|accessdate=29 June 2015|magazine=Australian Aviation|date=25 June 2015}} On 1 April 2014, ALG was renamed Air Mobility Group.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=6&iid=91526|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|title=Symbolic change is perfect timing|magazine=Air Force |volume=56 |issue=8|date=8 May
